title: Hosting Real Madrid in Kazakhstan : The diary of a Champions League underdog
body_text:
FC Kairat are the Champions League newcomers from Central Asia hoping to cause the mother of all upsets when they host Real Madrid.
Kairat are from the city of Almaty in south-eastern Kazakhstan, around 200 miles from the Chinese border and 3,985 miles from Madrid. The Spanish capital is closer to New York City â€” and the gap on the pitch is just as large.

Real Madrid are the record 15-time winners of the competition who have won the most matches in its history (301) and boast stars including Kylian Mbappe, Vinicius Junior and Jude Bellingham. This is Kairatâ€™s first appearance in the Champions League and their opening game against Sporting CP ended in a 4-1 defeat in Lisbon.
How have Kairat been preparing for the visit of one of the biggest clubs in the world? We spoke to a player, an analyst, the head groundskeeper, the press officer and a supporter turned club mainstay to find out.
The press officer
Kairatâ€™s 25-year-old press officer Arman Jaxygulov had an idea when the main Champions League draw took place in Monaco last month.
With the team gathered in Almaty, Jaxygulov decided to film their reaction. As Real Madridâ€™s league-phase opponents were revealed one by one by the UEFA computer, expectation grew. â€œKairat, Kairat!â€ one person shouts in the video, before a huge outburst of excitement when the Kazakhstani sideâ€™s name shows up on screen (â€˜Kairatâ€™ means strength or fortitude in Kazakh).

â€œOur players didnâ€™t know I was recording, so it was true emotion,â€ says Jaxygulov. â€œSome of them were really shocked.â€
The only other time Kairat played in the main phase of a UEFA competition, the inaugural Conference League in 2021-22, they finished bottom of their group. They progressed to the Champions League this year after winning the Kazakhstan top flight in 2024 â€” the season runs from March to late October or early November. But they still had to win four two-legged qualifying ties to even reach the league phase, culminating with a win on penalties against Scottish champions Celtic.
That has meant non-stop work for Jaxygulov, who also serves as club photographer and social media officer. It has reached another level with the visit of Madrid. Last week, they were filtering down 500 media accreditation requests from countries including Russia, Spain and Mexico to the 35 spaces left by UEFA and broadcasters for press at Almatyâ€™s Central Stadium.

The 20,800 tickets they put on sale last Tuesday quickly sold out â€” hardly a surprise given Madridâ€™s appeal in the region.
â€œIn Kazakhstan, every fifth person is a fan of Real Madrid or Barcelona,â€ says Jaxygulov. â€œEvery kid in every family has a Barcelona or Real Madrid jersey. They really like all the players, even from the second team and the third squad â€” they know the third goalkeeper of Real Madrid.â€
That could lead to an intriguing dynamic in the stadium, with plenty of Madrid fans expected to travel from neighbouring countries including China to see Xabi Alonsoâ€™s galacticos. For Kairatâ€™s promising 17-year-old forward Dastan Satpayev, who has agreed to join Chelsea next year for a reported â‚¬4m (Â£3.5m, $4.7m) when he turns 18, there is an extra incentive â€” he is a Barcelona fan.
Local interest in Madrid is so strong that Kairat decided not to allow fans to attend this afternoonâ€™s UEFA Youth League under-19 game between the two clubs, fearing that an overwhelming number of supporters turning up could cause a distraction.
The player
Four seasons ago, Kairatâ€™s Brazilian forward Edmilson was playing in the Portuguese third tier with Vilaverdense, a club from Braga.
This month, the 28-year-old became their first Champions League goalscorer when he netted an 86th-minute consolation after coming off the bench in the 4-1 defeat at Sporting. He barely slept on the eight-and-a-half-hour flight back to Almaty. â€œNow, with Madrid, I have to dream again,â€ the striker says.

Edmilson joined from Slovenian club Celje in June and readily admits he did not know a Kazakhstani team could play in European competition until Kairat came in for him. You canâ€™t blame him â€” the former Soviet Republic only became part of UEFA in 2002 by dint of a small western part of the country being classified as Europe. Kairat are the second team from the country to reach the main phase of the Champions League after Astana in 2015-16.

He suffered from nosebleeds when he first arrived in Almaty due to the cityâ€™s dry air and spent around a month adapting before he could play. He thinks that could make a difference against Madrid tonight. â€œMy body was very different, I felt like I wasnâ€™t strong enough to compete in training,â€ he says.
Edmilson hopes Kairat can hit Alonsoâ€™s side on the break and make the most of any tiredness from Saturdayâ€™s 5-2 derby defeat by Atletico Madrid and their eight-hour trip to Kazakhstan. He is excited to face his countryman Vinicius Junior but faces a fight to swap shirts with him after the game â€” the Brazil starâ€™s jersey is one of the most sought-after among Kairatâ€™s players.
Does he think Kairat stand a chance?
â€œThree years ago, no player who was with me would have said I was going to play in the Champions League against Madrid, but we have 90 minutes,â€ he says. â€œMadridâ€™s level is very, very high, but here, in Kazakhstan, everything is possible.â€
The analyst
When The Athletic spoke to Kairat performance analyst Alexander Kotlyar last week, he said his focus at the time was on â€œanalysing the opponent, planning tactical ideas, considering their strengths and weaknessesâ€.
To which the obvious question, at least before Real Madridâ€™s thrashing by Atletico, was: what weakness? â€œWe hope that we will find it, but I doubt it,â€ Kotlyar, 42, replied with a smile.
Kotlyar works with physical data and on the teamâ€™s psychology as well as serving as an interpreter between coach Rafael Urazbakhtin and the teamâ€™s English-speaking players. He has been at the club since 2013, first working as an academy coach, so he knows what it means for Kairat to be hosting Mbappe and Co.
â€œItâ€™s a great moment in our history. Not only for the club, in the history of our country,â€ he says. â€œItâ€™s another tempo, another rhythm â€” theyâ€™re players from another planet.â€

Kotlyar says he and his staff will prepare in the same way they would any other match, but also admits they might shift players from their usual positions. He would not be drawn on whether this meant they would try to stifle Alonsoâ€™s side.
â€œSomething will happen,â€ he said.
The groundskeeper
Kairat has already hosted one set of stars this month â€” the Backstreet Boys performed at Almatyâ€™s Central Stadium on September 19.
The clubâ€™s Ukrainian groundskeeper, Viktor Yaromenko, has been busy making sure the grass is at its very best after that gig by the U.S. group. That involved aerating the turf and applying chemicals to stop growth and prevent disease before the concert. He and his team of five â€” there will be five more for the day of the game â€” aerated the grass again afterwards and applied fertiliser, as well as mowing and brushing the pitch.
Yaromenko, 38, helped prepare the pitch at Kyivâ€™s Olympic Stadium for Real Madridâ€™s Champions League final win against Liverpool in 2018, below, and remembers watching Cristiano Ronaldo walk down the tunnel for the final time as a Madrid player before his move to Juventus that summer.
â€œI know what you feel when itâ€™s Real Madrid playing on your pitch,â€ says Yaromenko. â€œBut for this city, for this country, itâ€™s an amazing situation, (having) the best of the best clubs come to us.â€
UEFA inspected Kairatâ€™s hybrid pitch (a mix of natural grass and synthetic fibres) last Wednesday â€” which is more similar to other European grounds than others in Kazakhstan. Yaromenko says the turf was damaged for the qualifying tie against Celtic in August following a Jennifer Lopez concert earlier that month, but he is pleased with its condition for tonightâ€™s game.
â€œIf nobody has anything to say about the pitch, it means everything was OK,â€ he says.
The fan turned mainstay
If anyone is qualified to speak about Kairatâ€™s Champions League journey, it is Adil Karim.

The 26-year-old is a lifelong Kairat supporter who was once part of their official â€˜ultrasâ€™ group and now works for the club as their international relations manager, their main contact with UEFA and as the person responsible for dealing with FIFAâ€™s transfer matching system (TMS) â€” the online platform used by clubs to process moves. He was also present for the draw in Monaco.
On Saturday, Karim was at the Central Stadium to help UEFA prepare the stadium with the organisationâ€™s signage and LED advertising boards. Kairat have had to work hard to make adjustments to their 67-year-old ground to accommodate away fans, hospitality zones, and provide the media and interview zones required in European competition.
He is keen to point out Kairat are not here by chance. They are proud of their academy and modern training facilities â€” only Athletic Club and Ajax have more academy graduates in their Champions League squads than Kairatâ€™s 12. The Chelsea-bound Satpayev scored three goals and provided an assist in Champions League qualifying. Against Sporting, their third-choice goalkeeper Sherkhan Kalmurza, 18, became the second-youngest to save a penalty in Champions League history.
Karim is looking forward to meeting Alonso â€” a former Madrid player he grew up watching after his move from Liverpool â€” but his overwhelming feeling is one of pride that Kairat are rubbing shoulders with the elite. They will travel to three-time winners Inter in November and finish the league phase with a visit to Arsenal in January.
â€œWeâ€™re also a big team,â€ he says. â€œNow, weâ€™re also among the 36 biggest clubs in Europe. We are honoured to be one of them.â€
